message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Large language models empowered agent-based modeling and simulation: a survey and perspectives
Paper Abstract: Abstract Agent-based modeling and simulation have evolved as a powerful tool for modeling complex systems, offering insights into emergent behaviors and interactions among diverse agents. Recently, integrating large language models into agent-based modeling and simulation presents a promising avenue for enhancing simulation capabilities. This paper surveys the landscape of utilizing large language models in agent-based modeling and simulation, discussing their challenges and promising future directions. In this survey, since this is an interdisciplinary field, we first introduce the background of agent-based modeling and simulation and large language model-empowered agents. We then discuss the motivation for applying large language models to agent-based simulation and systematically analyze the challenges in environment perception, human alignment, action generation, and evaluation. Most importantly, we provide a comprehensive overview of the recent works of large language model-empowered agent-based modeling and simulation in multiple scenarios, which can be divided into four domains: cyber, physical, social, and hybrid, covering simulation of both real-world and virtual environments, and how these works address the above challenges. Finally, since this area is new and quickly evolving, we discuss the open problems and promising future directions. We summarize the representative papers along with their code repositories in https://github.com/tsinghua-fib-lab/LLM-Agent-Based-Modeling-and-Simulation .
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"},{"title":"BERT (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BERT_(language_model)"},{"title":"ELMo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ELMo"},{"title":"PaLM - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PaLM"},{"title":"Transformer (machine learning model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformer_(machine_learning_model)"},{"title":"GPT-3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about large language models:

## Definition

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Capabilities and Applications

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and other advanced features.

## Technical Foundation

As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture. The transformer architecture was proposed in the 2017 paper "Attention Is All You Need" by researchers at Google.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "agent-based modeling simulation"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Swarm (simulation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(simulation)"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"AnyLogic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AnyLogic"},{"title":"Vensim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vensim"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"}]

## Agent-Based Modeling Simulation

Here's an overview of agent-based modeling and simulation based on the search results:

### Definition

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

### How It Works

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.(no content)The process is one of emergence, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts—higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

### Key Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

### Applications

ABMs are used in many scientific domains including biology, ecology and social science.(no content)Agent-based models can be used to simulate a wide variety of social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts.

### Software Tools

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits. Popular tools include Swarm, GAMA, AnyLogic, and Repast.

## Agent-Based Modeling Simulation

Here's an overview of agent-based modeling and simulation based on the search results:

### Definition

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

### How It Works

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.(no content)The process is one of emergence, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts—higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.

### Key Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

### Applications

ABMs are used in many scientific domains including biology, ecology and social science.(no content)Agent-based models can be used to simulate a wide variety of social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts.

### Software Tools

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits. Popular tools include Swarm, GAMA, AnyLogic, and Repast.

Web search results for query: "environment perception artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Environmental impact of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_impact_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Machine perception - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_perception"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence for Environment & Sustainability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_for_Environment_&_Sustainability"},{"title":"Ambient intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"Cognitive science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_science"},{"title":"Percept (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percept_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Intelligent environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_environment"}]

I've completed a web search for "environment perception artificial intelligence." Here are the main findings:

## Key Concepts

**Machine Perception**: Machine perception is the capability of a computer system to interpret data in a manner that is similar to the way humans use their senses to relate to the world around them.(no content)The end goal of machine perception is to give machines the ability to see, feel and perceive the world as humans do and therefore for them to be able to explain in a human way why they are making their decisions.

**Intelligent Agents**: In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.(no content)The perception system gathers input from the environment via the sensors and feeds this information to a central controller, which then issues commands to the actuators.

**Perception in AI Systems**: AI is a field of research in computer science that develops and studies methods and software that enable machines to perceive their environment and use learning and intelligence to take actions that maximize their chances of achieving defined goals.

## Applications

Environmental perception is critical in autonomous vehicles. Artificial intelligence plays a pivotal role in the development and operation of autonomous vehicles, enabling them to perceive their surroundings, make decisions, and navigate safely without human intervention.

The search results reveal that environment perception is a fundamental aspect of AI that allows machines to sense and interpret their surroundings, which is essential for autonomous systems and intelligent agents to function effectively.

Web search results for query: "complex systems modeling simulation"

Links: [{"title":"Complex system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_system"},{"title":"Systems modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_modeling"},{"title":"Modeling and simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modeling_and_simulation"},{"title":"Computer simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_simulation"},{"title":"System-level simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System-level_simulation"},{"title":"Computational model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_model"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"System dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_dynamics"},{"title":"Complex adaptive system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_adaptive_system"},{"title":"Dynamical system simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system_simulation"}]

I've completed the web search for "complex systems modeling simulation." Here's a summary of what was found:

## Key Findings

**Definition and Overview:**
Complex systems often refers to the study of complex systems, which is an approach to science that investigates how relationships between a system's parts give rise to its collective behaviors and how the system interacts and forms relationships with its environment.

**Why Modeling is Important:**
The behavior of a complex system is intrinsically difficult to model due to the dependencies, competitions, relationships, and other types of interactions between their parts or between a given system and its environment.

**Main Characteristics:**
Systems that are "complex" have distinct properties that arise from these relationships, such as nonlinearity, emergence, spontaneous order, adaptation, and feedback loops, among others.

**Modeling and Simulation Approach:**
Modeling and simulation (M&S) is the use of models (e.g., physical, mathematical, behavioral, or logical representation of a system, entity, phenomenon, or process) as a basis for simulations to develop data utilized for managerial or technical decision making.

**Key Methodologies:**
The search results highlight several important approaches:
- System dynamics is a mathematical modeling technique to frame, understand, and discuss complex systems, originally developed in the 1950s to help corporate managers improve their understanding of industrial processes.
- Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.

**Benefits:**
M&S helps to reduce costs, increase the quality of products and systems, and document and archive lessons learned.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "action selection planning agent"

Links: [{"title":"Action selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_selection"},{"title":"Reactive planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_planning"},{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Deliberative agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_agent"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"GOAL agent programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GOAL_agent_programming_language"},{"title":"Situated approach (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Situated_approach_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Agentic AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Simultaneous action selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_action_selection"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about action selection planning agents:

## Overview

Action selection is a way of characterizing the most basic problem of intelligent systems: what to do next. In artificial intelligence and computational cognitive science, "the action selection problem" is typically associated with intelligent agents and animats—artificial systems that exhibit complex behavior in an agent environment.

## Approaches to Action Selection

There are several main approaches to implementing action selection in planning agents:

**Goal-Driven Architectures**: In these symbolic architectures, the agent's behavior is typically described by a set of goals. Each goal can be achieved by a process or an activity, which is described by a prescripted plan. The agent must just decide which process to carry on to accomplish a given goal.

**Distributed Systems**: In contrast to the symbolic approach, distributed systems of action selection actually have no one "box" in the agent that decides the next action. At least in their idealized form, distributed systems have many modules running in parallel and determining the best action based on local expertise.

**Reactive Planning**: In artificial intelligence, reactive planning denotes a group of techniques for action selection by autonomous agents. They operate in a timely fashion and hence can cope with highly dynamic and unpredictable environments.

## Modern AI Agents

AI agents possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems. Their control flow is frequently driven by large language models (LLMs). Agents also include memory systems for remembering previous user-agent interactions and orchestration software for organizing agent components.

## Overview

Action selection is a way of characterizing the most basic problem of intelligent systems: what to do next. In artificial intelligence and computational cognitive science, "the action selection problem" is typically associated with intelligent agents and animats—artificial systems that exhibit complex behavior in an agent environment.

## Approaches to Action Selection

There are several main approaches to implementing action selection in planning agents:

**Goal-Driven Architectures**: In these symbolic architectures, the agent's behavior is typically described by a set of goals. message_text:
Excellent! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what I've done:

## Paper Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

The paper "Large language models empowered agent-based modeling and simulation: a survey and perspectives" is classified as a **survey** paper since it reviews and synthesizes existing work in the field of LLM-empowered agent-based simulation.

**Triples Identified and Validated:** 8 entities

I've extracted the following key concepts from the paper's title and abstract and mapped them to Wikipedia articles:

1. **Agent-based model** (method) - Core methodology surveyed
2. **Large language model** (artifact) - Central technology being integrated
3. **Complex system** (concept) - Type of systems being modeled
4. **Machine perception** (method) - Addresses environment perception challenge
5. **Action selection** (method) - Relates to action generation challenge
6. **Intelligent agent** (concept) - Fundamental entity in agent-based modeling
7. **Simulation** (method) - Core computational technique
8. **Automated planning and scheduling** (method) - Related to agent decision-making

All triples have been validated successfully:
- ✅ Paper type is correctly set to "survey"
- ✅ All 8 triples are properly formatted
- ✅ All Wikipedia URLs are valid and verified
- ✅ Each triple includes proper entity type, relation (all "uses" as expected for a survey), and relevance statement

Sources:
- [Agent-based model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model)
- [Large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model)
- [Complex system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_system)
- [Machine perception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_perception)
